awd_titl_txt: Degenerate Diffusions and Related Heat Kernel Estimates
awd_abstract_narration:
This research project lies at the intersection of several areas of mathematics: probability, analysis and differential geometry. The PI will work on problems related to diffusion processes and their heat kernels in degenerate geometric settings, merging tools of the three mentioned areas. Some of the problems are pertinent to various applied fields, including mathematical finance, control of dynamic systems, machine learning, and others. The PI will integrate her research expertise into teaching probability courses, mentoring students, and organizing conferences. The PI will also continue her effort in encouraging women and other underrepresented groups in math.
 
The project focuses on random diffusion processes that are subject to a priori non-holonomic constraints which can perfectly fit into the framework of sub-Riemannian geometry. A recurring theme of proposed topics is the interaction between the underlying geometric structure and the limiting behaviors of the associated Markov processes. The project is primarily concerned with three topics. The first is to study stochastic processes and the explicit heat kernel on sub-Riemannian model spaces, which provides great examples and strong intuition for the understanding of general cases. The second topic concerns the limiting behaviors -in both small and large time scale -of a general degenerate diffusion process, which reflect the underlying geometric information of geodesic and Ricci curvature bound respectively. The third topic is to study the heat content of bounded domains in a sub-Riemannian manifold, which reveals the geometry of the domain such as surface area and total mean curvature of the boundary.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

This Project Outcomes Report for the General Public is displayed verbatim as submitted by the Principal Investigator (PI) for this award. Any opinions, findings, and conclusions or recommendations expressed in this Report are those of the PI and do not necessarily reflect the views of the National Science Foundation; NSF has not approved or endorsed its content.

This project is devoted to the study of stochastic processes in manifolds that are equipped with degenerate metric, known as sub-Riemannian manifolds. This geometric structure has implications in control theory and physics.

The PI first studies the Brownian motion processes on model spaces of sub-Riemannian geometry, particularly the Stiefel manifolds, which reflect their sub-Riemannian structure through their fibration. This study characterized the laws of the associated stochastic area and the stochastic winding processes, and revealed connections between the theory of random matrices and Brownian motions on high rank symmetric spaces.

The PI then explored the interplay between probability and analysis in her investigation on the "tug of war" between the bottom of the spectrum of a domain and the mean exit time of a Brownian motion from that domain. With her coauthors, the PI quantified this competition over a wide range of domains in a general metric measure space setting. This research integrated tools from the theory of Dirichlet forms, heat kernel analysis, spectral theory, as well as probability theory. This research also contributed to advancements in the study of the Hot Spots conjecture.

Furthermore,  the PI investigated the geometric influence of degenerate geometry on the diffusions with random potential. Specifically, she studied the parabolic Anderson model (PAM) on the Heisenberg groups, which serve as flat models of sub-Riemannian manifolds. With coauthors, she characterized the conditions guaranteeing the existence and uniqueness of PAM solutions. This research led to discussions on related topics, such as the intermittency phenomena and directed polymer models, with far-reaching implications in physics, engineering, and mathematical finance.

Throughout the grant period, 8 papers and 1 book have been produced, some of them are published in high quality peer reviewed journals.  Research findings have been widely disseminated through invited talks delivered by the PI at various conferences and during research visits.  Additionally,  the PI provided active mentorship to 4 undergraduate students, 1 graduate student, and 1 postdoc. Engaging in diversity and outreach initiatives, the PI has consistently served as a mentor for the Emerging Leaders Science Scholars Program and participated as a panelist for the high school summer camp at Purdue.
